    Coupled cluster singles

    By Dylan Jayatilaka June 16, 2014 June 07, 0201 Permalink

    The coupled cluster single (CCS) wavefunction has the form

    Here we have introduced the single excitation operator \( T_I^A \) which is defined by \( \sum_I^{N\sub{o}} \sum_A^{N\sub{v}} \).

    The CCS wavefunction is just a determinent wavefunction

    We can carry out further simplifications to the equations above:

    The second line follows from the properties of the exponential function.

    The final line follows from the fact that \( (\sum_I T_I^A)^2 = 0) i.e. it is not possible to substitute spinorbital \( I \) more than once.

    In fact, the final line can be written as an (unnormalized) single determinant \( \Phi’ \) made from new spinorbitals \( phi’\sub{I} \) like this,

    Therefore the \( T_1 \) operator in the coupled cluster wavefunction causes a mixture of unoccupied spinorbitals into the reference orbitals.

    The CCS wavefunction for a HF reference has zero amplitudes
